head.title: The Lost Joys of Family Time

hedline.hl1: The Lost Joys of Family Time

abstract.p: Patricia Schnaider letter responds to June 13 news article on parents trying to reclaim their children's time; criticizes parents for failing to lead their families; drawing

block.p: ''Parents Try to Reclaim Their Children's Time'' (news article, June 13) noted parents' fears of what might be lost by cutting back afterschool activities, like potential college athletic scholarship money.

It seems as if ''family values'' often suffer from a lack of focus on developing healthy children and are instead represented by parents' own ego-driven pursuit to make their children better athletes while benchmarking their community with wins and losses.

''Parents Try to Reclaim Their Children's Time'' (news article, June 13) noted parents' fears of what might be lost by cutting back afterschool activities, like potential college athletic scholarship money.

It seems as if ''family values'' often suffer from a lack of focus on developing healthy children and are instead represented by parents' own ego-driven pursuit to make their children better athletes while benchmarking their community with wins and losses.

A child's personal development should be the primary consideration when helping them make healthy lifestyle choices. Instead, many of us are teaching our children to be ''mini me's,'' driven by a frenetic pace with no time left for growth or (gasp!) fun.
MICHAEL B. SNYDER Pittsford, N.Y., June 13, 2000
